Candace Cameron Bure, Jodie Sweetin, Andrea Barber will return for new series.<n>John Stamos will produce and guest star in "Fuller House"<n>The show will be available next year on Netflix.

A new medical technology could help end polio.<n>The microneedle patch could bring polio vaccines to the doorsteps of the people that need them.

Near-sightedness has doubled, even tripled, in most of East Asia over the last 40 years.<n>Methopia rates among 20-year-olds in South Korea have leaped from 18% in 1955 to over 96% in 2011.<n>Researchers say reducing risk of myopia is easy, free and readily-available: Get some sunlight.
Hillary Clinton should announce she'll take a pay cut if elected president.<n>Closure of the pay gap would help working women and stimulate the economy.

TSA officers would alert a female TSA officer when a man they found attractive was walking through.<n>The female officer would then tell the screening machine that a female passenger was walking through.<n>That information would trigger a machine to register an anomaly in the groin area.

Proposed NYPD training materials are submitted to a federal judge for approval.<n>They remind cadets not to engage in racial profiling and to avoid ethnic jokes.<n>The training materials are a result of a 2013 federal ruling declaring the NYPD's "Stop, Question and Frisk" practice unconstitutional.

"Smart bullets" equipped with optical sensors pass most successful live-fire tests to date.<n>A novice shooter using the system for the first time hit a moving target, DARPA says.
Sarah Brady, 73, died of pneumonia, her family says.<n>She and her husband pushed for stricter gun control laws.<n>James Brady was shot in the head during an attempt on President Reagan's life.

Kenya's deputy president tells U.N. to move refugees from world's largest refugee camp to Somalia.<n>William Ruto says Kenya will "relocate them ourselves" at Dadaab camp in Somalia.<n>The U.N. refugee agency says it hasn't received a formal request from Kenya.
Greenpeace: Six activists boarded a Shell oil rig 750 miles northwest of Hawaii.<n>The group is protesting the company's plans to drill in the Arctic near Alaska.

Vladimir Putin will take questions from the public during a televised Q&A on Thursday.<n>The annual event has become a tradition for Russians, and a chance to grill the president.<n>This year, the public has shown great interest, with 200,000 submitting questions in the first hour.
Officials: Saudi airstrikes hit a school near a military base in southwestern Yemen.<n>At least a half dozen students were injured at the school, officials say.
Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri was a top deputy to Saddam Hussein.<n>He was killed in an operation near Tikrit, a militia commander says.

Solar Impulse 2 has been grounded in China for two-and-a-half weeks.<n>Pilots say the latest setback is due to bad weather conditions.<n>The plane is attempting to fly around the world without using a drop of fuel.
ISIS sees itself as a government operating under a rule of law.<n>Some subjects would be banned -- democracy and political thought, also hotel management and tourism and archaeology.

Chinese government releases five young feminists on bail.<n>The women were detained just before the International Women's Day.<n>They were planning a campaign against sexual harassment on public transportation.

Paul Nungesser was cleared of responsibility in his accuser's 2013 rape claim.<n>But Emma Sulkowicz publicly called him a "serial rapist" after he was cleared.<n>Nungesser is suing Columbia University for discrimination.

President Obama and Cuban President Raul Castro shake hands at a dinner.<n>The meeting is so important that a National Security Council spokesperson issued a statement.<n>The two nations have barely been on speaking terms -- officially -- for more than 50 years.
Joseph Kent was released from jail, his lawyer says.<n>He was arrested after a citywide curfew went into effect.

Earthquakes have devastated Nepal, leaving thousands homeless.<n>Numerous relief organizations are on the ground in Nepal helping the survivors.<n>If you want to help, donations can be as simple as sending a text.
SpaceX founder Elon Musk says the rocket landed "too hard for survival"<n>The private space exploration company has said it will keep trying.
Justice Anthony Kennedy, considered a key vote for challengers to the state bans, was back in a familiar role.<n>Chief Justice John Roberts seemed to lean more closely to conservative justices.
Freddie Gray, 25, died a week after he was arrested.<n>It's unclear how he suffered a severe spinal cord injury.

The U.N. appeals for $174 million to help Nigerian refugees who've fled militant attacks.<n>Boko Haram has killed thousands in the nation's northeast.<n>192,000 people have fled to neighboring nations.

dashcam video shows Inkster, Michigan, police officer punching unarmed motorist.<n>On Monday, a prosecutor charged the officer with assault and mistreatment of a prisoner.<n>On Wednesday, drug charges against the motorist were dropped, clearing him of wrongdoing.

U.S. officials say China is developing its own submarine forces.<n>A Pentagon research group is developing an unmanned drone ship to track enemy submarines.<n>The so-called drone ships will be 132 feet long and likely cost about $20 million.
Grass died in a clinic in Luebeck, his publisher says.<n>He won the Nobel literature prize in 1999.<n> Grass confessed to being in the Waffen SS as a teen.
Feidin Santana says he was told to stop by another officer.<n>He says he saw the officer shoot Scott but never saw him try to fight.
At least 1,800 people are dead, U.N. says.<n>The quake was the strongest in the region in more than 80 years.

Japanese police say they arrested a 64-year-old man over allegations he photographed an obscene act with a girl of 13 or 14.<n>Yuhei Takashima told police he began paying for sex with women in 1988 when he went to work in Manila.<n>He said the ages of the prostitutes he hired ranged from 14 to over 70.

Pappy Van Winkle, a 20-year-old bourbon, was reported missing in October 2013.<n>Nine people have been indicted in the case.<n>The alleged ringleader is Gilbert "Toby" Curtsinger, a 45-year-old loading dock worker.
Police estimate that 275,000 demonstrators marched in Sao Paulo.<n>Protesters are angry over a corruption scandal involving President Dilma Rousseff.
Freddie Gray should have received medical attention at the scene of his arrest, police say.<n>Police commissioner says there are no excuses for the fact that Gray was not buckled in.

CyArk is a company that specializes in digital preservation of threatened ancient and historical architecture.<n>It uses groundbreaking laser scanning to ensure that incredibly accurate digital versions of the world's treasures will stay with us forever.<n>Ben Kacyra was born in Mosul, Iraq, in 1940, and was instrumental in the design of the first portable laser scanner.
The United Nations has released its third World Happiness Report.<n>Switzerland tops the list as the happiest country on Earth.

President Barack Obama and Cuban President Raul Castro meet for the first time in more than 50 years.<n>Obama says the meeting could be a "turning point" in his push to thaw relations with Cuba.<n>Castro says there are still "difficult" stumbling blocks to overcome.

Migrant deaths in the Mediterranean have increased by a factor of 30 this year.<n>Almost all the deaths have occurred in the central Mediterranean crossing from Libya to Italy.<n>The EU has unveiled a new ten-point action plan to deter asylum seekers.

Edwin Sabuhoro is a wildlife warden in Rwanda's Volcanoes National Park.<n>He helped put poachers in prison by posing as a potential buyer for a gorilla.<n>He then turned his savings to help them make a living farming.
30 Ethiopians are among the two groups executed, the Ethiopian government says.<n>The al-Furqan Media video shows two groups of men being killed.
Photographer Ernst Haas was a regular on movie sets.<n>His images are now being published in a new book.
Record Store Day is Saturday.<n>Many stores will host live performances, drawings, book signings.
Morsy's Freedom and Justice Party calls the trial a "travesty of justice"<n>Morsy can appeal his conviction.

Ancient surgical tools were often made from obsidian.<n>The volcanic glass can produce cutting edges many times finer than steel scalpels.<n>Small number of surgeons now using ancient technology to carry out fine incisions.

Italian prosecutor: Al Qaeda-linked group discussed attacking the Vatican in 2010.<n>U.S. congressman: This is "a reminder about the world we're in right now"<n>A man in Paris was arrested after allegedly targeting a church and a woman.
The torching of a Christian church is one of many attacks against Christians in Egypt.<n>The 71 sentenced are mostly in absentia, with 21 already in prison.

Robert Bates pleads not guilty to second-degree manslaughter charge.<n>He is accused of shooting and killing Eric Harris after Harris fled from officers.<n>Bates says he meant to stun Harris, but shot him with a gun instead.

Every culture remakes Jesus in its own image, from the Anglo-Protestant 1970s to the 9/11 attacks of 2001.<n>Hollywood has yet to cast an actual Jew as Jesus.<n>But a new vision of Jesus came into view this weekend, as TV remakes aired.

Charleston mayor says he and the Scott family are exhausted.<n>Police meet with man who was in Walter Scott's car when officer pulled it over.<n>Scott family attorney says the man was a co-worker and friend.

Fatu Kekula was just a year away from finishing up her nursing degree in Liberia.<n>She treated all four of her Ebola-stricken relatives at the same time.<n>A CNN story about her prompted donations from around the world.
Video shows Walter Scott and North Charleston Officer Michael Slager speaking.<n>Scott gets out of his car, again, and runs away.

Jon Reiter says 17 people have been killed on Mount Everest.<n>An Indian Army spokesman says 13 of its climbers have been evacuated.<n>A doctor says he has seen 14 bodies; others say many more are dead.
Cleveland Clinic sought help from Diane von Furstenberg in updating hospital gowns.<n>Part of a trend among hospitals to improve patient reviews and bottom lines, says expert.

Ben and Shelby Offrink met in college and had two children together.<n>In 2014, Shelby was diagnosed with an aggressive form of brain cancer.<n>Ben got some terrible news: His Hodgkins lymphoma had reappeared.

Swiss physicist Jean-Pierre Wolf is working on using focused laser beams to affect the weather.<n>It's a cleaner version of cloud seeding, a form of weather modification that has been used for several years, most famously by China for the 2008 Olympics.<n>Wolf says that once it's perfected, it could help us modulate the weather in areas of high contrast, such as California or Chile.
Aaron Hernandez is found guilty of first-degree murder.<n>He also faces murder charges in a 2012 double homicide.

Dr. Anthony Moschetto is accused of plotting to take out a rival cardiologist on Long Island.<n>His attorney says the allegations against his client are "completely unsubstantiated"<n>Two other men have been charged in the case.

Peshmerga commander: More than 200 Yazidis were released.<n>Most of those freed were women and children, the commander says.<n>Yazidis are of Kurdish descent, and their religion is considered a pre-Islamic sect.

ISIS has benefited from a media environment that amplifies its propaganda, law enforcement officials say.<n>The group quickly reached early recruits through videos that showcased the fear its adherents instilled in nonbelievers.
Police say 12 people were arrested.<n>Protesters and police get into physical altercations.<n>Family of Freddie Gray asks for peace.

Jackson Gordon is an industrial design student at Philadelphia University.<n>He has created a Batsuit, complete with armor plating and a cape.<n>Gordon raised $1,255 on Kickstarter to fund the creation of the suit.

Mary Jane Veloso's family was returning from what they thought was their final visit to the prison.<n>A Philippine TV crew flagged their bus down to tell them of the decision to postpone her execution.<n>"We are so happy, so happy. I thought I had lost my daughter already," her mother tells CNN.

New York police push protesters back; more than 60 arrested.<n>Hundreds of people march in New York, Washington, Minneapolis.<n>Protests were in support of Baltimore protesters and to complain about police violence.
Zuriel Oduwole is a 12-year-old filmmaker from Nigeria.<n>Her latest project is a series on African nations.<n>She has interviewed 14 heads of state.

Christian Assyrians in northern Iraq have formed a militia to fight ISIS.<n>The militia has only assembled and trained 40 fighters.<n>"We simply do not have enough weapons and training capacities," says one member.
Typhoon Maysak is weakening, but could still become a tropical storm when it reaches the Philippines.<n>The storm is projected to make landfall on the island of Luzon on Sunday.

France's Marquis de Lafayette fought with George Washington in the War of Independence.<n>L'Hermione is a replica of the frigate that helped Washington defeat the British.<n>It set sail from France on Saturday for Virginia to retrace Lafayette's journey.
Selena Dohal, 8, has a fractured skull and urgently needs surgery.<n>Dr. Sanjay Gupta is helping at Bir Hospital in Kathmandu.<n>Gupta scrubbed up at the request of a Nepalese medical team.
India says it will send 10 more aid flights to Nepal.<n>Red Cross opens blood bank; reports indicate hospitals are overflowing with patients.

The FBI says it will investigate whether civil rights were violated.<n>Video shows deputies using a stun gun on a man, then repeatedly kicking and hitting him.<n>Ten deputies identified as being involved in the case have been put on paid administrative leave.

Nepal's only international airport is jam-packed with cargo planes.<n>The government is struggling to transport aid due to mountainous terrain.<n>Access to remote areas is also difficult due to collapsed bridges and damaged roads.
A French search and rescue team finds a man trapped under rubble 82 hours after the quake.<n>Rishi Khanal had undergone surgery and was resting, surrounded by family and friends.
Turkey recalls its ambassador to the Vatican for "consultations"<n>Turkey's foreign minister calls the Pope's use of the word "unacceptable"
47 bodies have been exhumed from two mass graves in Tikrit, an Iraqi official says.<n>A total of 11 mass graves have been discovered in Tikrit.<n>Grieving Iraqis gathered to pray over the bodies.
Police: More than 100 people arrested during the rioting were released without charges.<n>Protests are planned for Thursday in Cincinnati, Philadelphia and Seattle, reports say.

Katie Donovan and Dalton Prager met online, fell in love and got married.<n>Cystic fibrosis patients shouldn't be near each other because they can share infections.<n>Katie's pulmonologist had lectured her many times that face-to-face meetings with other CF patients were a bad idea.
Noelle Velentzas and Asia Siddiqui are accused of planning to build an explosive device.<n>They appeared in federal court in Brooklyn on Thursday.
North Charleston police Officer Michael Slager is charged with murder.<n>Video shows him shoot Walter Scott as he runs away.<n>Scott was a father of four and a former Coast Guard member.
Two African-American candidates win seats on Ferguson City Council.<n>Their victories make the council 50% black.<n>Ferguson's population is 70% black, but the council was predominantly white.
U.N. agency calls for aid access to Yarmouk refugee camp.<n>The camp is home to thousands of Palestinians.<n>Activists report ISIS and al Qaeda-affiliated groups have taken control of the camp.
abra Dipping Co. recalls 30,000 cases of hummus.<n>Listeria monocytogenes was found in a random sample at a Michigan store.

Walter Scott, 50, was killed by a police officer after a traffic stop.<n>A lawyer says Scott had outstanding warrants for not paying child support.<n>His brother says Scott was outgoing and loved his family.
Lane Bryant is challenging Victoria's Secret with a new ad campaign.<n>The campaign is titled #ImNoAngel.<n>Victoria's Secret has been criticized for its ads in the past.
Many Clouds, ridden by Leighton Aspell, wins the Grand National.<n>The 25-1 outsider won by a length and a half.<n>Record breaking jockey AP McCoy finishes fifth.

The Sewol ferry sank on April 16, killing 304 people, mostly high school students.<n>Divers have not searched the wreckage because of the winter and water conditions.<n>Nine people have yet to be found.

Al-Shabaab has targeted schools in northern Kenya, targeting "Western" education.<n>The group wants to make sure "everything goes negative," the headmaster says.<n>In April, Al-Shabaab massacred 147 people at Garissa University in northern Kenya.
Gunman had backpack and suitcase that authorities treated as suspicious.<n>Gunman had a sign about "social justice," witness says.<n>Police chief says there is "no nexus to terrorism"
Two people were shot in the neck and another was shot in the leg.<n>A suspect is in custody in the neck shooting.<n>The two victims shot in the neck were hospitalized.
The C-130 is the oldest continuously produced family of military planes in history.<n>Georgia's governor christened the first production C-130A at Lockheed's Marietta, Georgia, factory in 1955.
Many have referred to Hillary Clinton as "Hillary" since she announced her candidacy.<n>John F. Sutter: We've long called Clinton by her first name, and her first name only.
"Galaxy Quest" is the latest movie to be adapted for TV.<n>It's the latest Paramount film to be turned into a series.
Nicholas Slatten gets life in prison for first-degree murder conviction.<n>Three others are sentenced to 30 years each.<n>The shooting in 2007 in Baghdad killed 17 people.
Grand jury declines to indict two officers in fatal shooting of schizophrenic man.<n>Officers are still facing a wrongful death lawsuit from Jason Harrison's family.

Red Cross: Many wounded in airstrikes and fighting will die if not tended to soon.<n>Group calls for pause in fighting in and near southern Yemeni port city of Aden.<n>U.N. Security Council meets to discuss Yemen; no decision announced.
India has evacuated 2,500 people from Yemen in the last few days, official says.<n>Air India has been helping to evacuate people from Yemen's capital.
Investigators and Red Cross crews finish removing bodies of students killed in attack.<n>Shattered glass and shell casings littered the floor of Garissa University College.

NASA scientist: "We know where to look. We know how to look"<n>She says we'll have definitive evidence of alien life in 20 to 30 years.<n>John Grunsfeld: We're "one generation away" in our solar system.

New South China Mall was opened to the public in 2005 in Dongguan in the south of the country.<n>The goal was to attract 100,000 visitors a day with an array of entertainment, shops and eateries.<n>Soon, it was classified by industry analysts as a "dead mall" and it became an unflattering symbol of China's runaway speculation on real estate projects.<n>But a visit in late March revealed a different picture. The mall was buzzing with activity.
ISIS fighters take 3 northern Ramadi districts, an Iraqi provincial official says.<n>10 Iraqi security forces were killed in the attacks, he adds.

Two Australians are on death row in Indonesia for a heroin smuggling plot.<n>A court rejected their last ditch effort to gain clemency from the president.<n>The Bali Nine were arrested after Indonesian police received a tip from Australian police.
Brynn Duncan, 21, has food allergies that can cause a massive reaction.<n>She was hospitalized for a near-death experience.
UNICEF: 800,000 children have been forced to flee their homes in Nigeria.<n>The number has more than doubled in less than a year, the agency says.
911 caller made threat to blow up Statue of Liberty, National Park Service says.<n>Police bomb squad examined a locker thought to contain a suspicious package and found it empty.

Brian Rogers and Caitlin McGuire own the Breckenridge Cannabis Club in Colorado.<n>The pair started their business as a medical cannabis dispensary in 2010.<n>In 2014, Colorado became the first state in the nation to allow the sale of recreational marijuana.
The U.S. is closing down its longest war in Afghanistan.<n>The last of the U.S. troops will be out by the end of next year.<n>CNN's Nick Paton Walsh visits a logistics hub for the Afghan police.
Protesters are calling for President Dilma Rousseff to be impeached.<n>Her approval rating has plummeted to 13%.<n>The country is in the midst of an economic downturn.
Iraqi forces, aided by Shiite militiamen, took control of Tikrit on Wednesday.<n>CNN team sees vehicles laden with explosives, buildings that might be booby-trapped.
Detective Patrick Cherry says he was angry at the driver.<n>Video shows the detective yelling at the driver and mocking his accent.

Police say a drone with traces of radioactive material was found on the roof of Abe's residence.<n>A staff member spotted the drone on the roof of Abe's residence, police say.<n>The drone had a small camera, smoke flares and a plastic bottle containing traces of cesium, police say.

UltraHaptics creates tactile three-dimensional shapes literally out of thin air.<n>Technology creates sensations through sound waves and air pressure.<n>Could be used to control virtual reality devices and more.

CNN's Laura Bernardini is a lifelong Catholic and a director of coverage.<n>She's never read the Bible from Genesis to Revelation.<n>A colleague suggested she read the Bible each day for a year and chronicle it weekly for Belief.
Google Maps turns your desktop into a Pac-Man course.<n>The game was a prank for April Fools' Day.

Rick Santorum said he hoped Indiana's governor would veto the "fix" to the state's religious freedom law.<n>The law was criticized by many, including tech giants like Apple and sports organizations like the NCAA.<n>The law was later changed to make clear it couldn't be used to refuse services based on sexual orientation.

China launches app featuring latest speeches, statements and publications by President Xi Jinping.<n>Designed by the Central Party School, which trains Chinese Communist Party leaders, the app aims to "arouse enthusiasm" for socialist ideologies.<n>It's unclear how many people have downloaded the app, which is available on Apple's App Store.
Aaron Hernandez is known for his swagger.<n>He is often impeccably dressed in suit and tie brought in by his defense team.
Mitchell is in intensive care, her website said.<n>She was found unconscious at her Los Angeles home Tuesday.
Writers: Too much job growth is in part-time low-income work.<n>They say Congress should help low-wage workers gain access to predictable work schedules.
Crowd at Uhuru Park remembers the 147 victims of the Garissa university attack.<n>"I can't even look at pictures of the people killed without crying," one woman says.

Israel will not accept a deal that allows Iran to develop nuclear weapons, Netanyahu says.<n>He says the framework agreement would legitimize Iran's nuclear program.<n>Netanyahu: Iran is arming its terror proxies to attack Israel.
Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam, Holland America says.<n>The FBI is on scene investigating, a spokesman said.

147 people were killed in the attack at Garissa University College.<n>Kenya's politicians and public have struggled with the idea of beefing up security.<n>The battle with Al-Shabaab is not a new one, and every attempt has stalled an attack.

An Indian army team plans to trek up Mount Everest to pick up trash left by climbers.<n>The team will bring back at least 4,000 kilograms of waste from the high-altitude camps, India Today reports.<n>The upcoming trip marks the 50th anniversary of the first Indian team to scale the mountain.

Severe weather is predicted for the Midwest and Plains on Thursday and Friday.<n>Tornadoes can be more deadly when people are sleeping and not paying attention to the warnings, CNN meteorologist says.

Severe weather is predicted for the Midwest and Plains on Thursday and Friday.<n>Tornadoes can be more deadly when people are sleeping and not paying attention to the warnings, CNN meteorologist says.

Iran's President says his country won't fight or surrender to other powers.<n>He thanks Iranians for their patience and for "resisting" by standing up for his rights.<n>Rouhani says Iran will be true to its word if other countries live up to their promises.

Achievers Ghana is an education project in the heart of Accra, Ghana.<n>It aims to provide girls with the education and role models they need to succeed.<n>The project is supported by tech entrepreneur Regina Agyare, who runs a coding club for local teens.

CNN's Zain Verjee was approached by a man offering to "foster" children in a displaced camp in Nigeria.<n>The man told Verjee he would reward her if she chose to take the children.<n>Nigeria has the highest number of people in modern slavery of any sub-Saharan country, according to the Global Slavery Index.

Cynthia Cheroitich describes hiding in a closet, fearing for her life.<n>She was one of the students at Garissa University College attacked by Al-Shabaab.<n>Police on Saturday paraded the bodies of suspected militants.

Judge says "lurid details" of alleged abuse are unnecessary.<n>Lawyer Alan Dershowitz says allegations against him are "completely false and made up"<n>Bucks Palace: Prince Andrew is spending this week privately, resuming public engagements.

Talks between the U.S., Iran and the EU continue into the early hours, a U.S. official says.<n>Iran's foreign minister says his country has shown "its readiness to engage with dignity"<n>The deadline for a comprehensive deal on Iran's nuclear program is June 30.

Aviation experts are calling for enhanced crash avoidance software.<n>The technology could take control of an aircraft away from a pilot and steer it to a safe altitude.<n>The technology would work in a fashion similar to crash avoidance technology already used in automobiles.

A commercial fishing vessel carrying 132 people sank off the Kamchatka Peninsula in Russia, the ministry of culture says.<n>At least 54 people have died and 15 others are missing, according to state-run Tass news agency.
Stan Freberg was godfather of humorous and irreverent commercials.<n>Freberg died of natural causes at a Santa Monica hospital.<n>He was known for his musical parodies.

Indiana Gov. Mike Pence said the state will "fix" the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.<n>Eric Liu: Promoting the false dichotomy between protecting religion versus protecting equality serves no one.

"Furious 7" is expected to gross $115 million or more when opening at the North American box office this weekend.<n>The movie is getting the widest release in Universal's history with a theater count of roughly 4,003.<n>"Furious 7" is also poised to do massive business, putting its global debut north of $250 million.
Lane Smith died in July after falling and hitting his head.<n>His wife asked a photographer to use one of their family pictures with Smith.<n>The photo has become a social media sensation.
Indiana's religious freedom law has sparked a national debate.<n>The law's supporters say it is a copy of a federal law.<n>Here are five things to consider when thinking about the controversy.
A bronze statue of Lucille Ball in her hometown has drawn criticism.<n>Fans want it removed, saying it's an "ugly" likeness.

Muhammadu Buhari, 72, won Nigeria's presidential election.<n>It's his first time in nearly 30 years and comes after a long history of military rule.<n>He campaigned as a born-again democrat to allay fears about his strict military regime.
Iranians erupted in celebration as young people waved flags from their sunroofs.<n>The excitement came after a breakthrough nuclear deal with the United States and other world powers.
Dilkhayot Kasimov was added to a superseding indictment in a Brooklyn court.<n>Three other men were charged last month with providing support to a foreign terrorist organization.
The moon turns red in a total lunar eclipse.<n>It's the third in a series of four in a row, known as a "tetrad"

Dozens of cities across Turkey lost power for hours on Tuesday.<n>Millions of people were affected, including passengers stranded on paralyzed trains and subways.<n>The energy minister suggested a possible failure in transmission lines.
McDonald's announced it would raise wages for 90,000 of its employees.<n>Van Jones: This is a significant victory for fast-food workers.
Gov. Jerry Brown orders mandatory water restrictions for the first time.<n>The 25% cut in usage amounts to roughly 1.5 million acre-feet of water.

Britain's general election is taking place Thursday.<n>The Queen is not officially in charge of Britain, but she's nominally in charge.<n>In the U.S., voters choose their president, but in the UK they vote for a new prime minister.
Bill Emmott: Christians should reflect upon persecution of Christians worldwide.<n>He says it's not an exaggerated or contrived crisis.

Ferguson court clerk fired after racist emails found during Justice Department probe.<n>Two police officers resigned after the emails were discovered.<n>Emails made offensive references to President Obama, first lady Michelle Obama.

Two people have been arrested in Australia after at least 55 dog carcasses were found dumped in Queensland bush.<n>The pair, a 71-year old man and a 64-year old woman, were each charged with one count of unlawful possession of a firearm.<n>The woman, a licensed trainer, was also charged with obstructing police.
Memories Gourmet Pizza Co. is in Nichols, Wisconsin.<n>People mistake it for Memories Pizza of Walkerton, Indiana.<n>"My stomach was in my throat all afternoon," says co-owner Kathy Danke.

The skeleton of a camel was found beneath a cellar in the Austrian city of Tulln.<n>Researchers say it is the first complete skeleton of a camel found in Central Europe.<n>The skeleton was a "Tulu" hybrid, with offspring of a dromedary and a Bactrian.

Andrew Getty's death "appears to be natural (causes) or an accident," coroner's official says.<n>A female friend was at the home where Getty died, police say.<n>He was the grandson of oil tycoon J. Paul Getty.
Andreas Lubitz crashed Germanwings Flight 9525 into the French Alps on March 24.<n>David Perry: We need to understand mental illness and not a personal failing.

Kamron Taylor, 23, is arrested in Chicago after allegedly assaulting a guard and escaping jail.<n>The sheriff in his county says the convicted murderer will likely face attempted murder charges.<n>He says Taylor, who has a tattoo of the name Gertrude on his neck, won't be free for long.

Prince Harry is due to arrive in Australia on Monday for a four-week stint with the armed forces there.<n>He will work and live alongside colleagues in the Australian Army in Sydney, Darwin and Perth.<n>He has already spent time with Australian troops on a number of occasions.

Two Florida corrections officers and one former officer trainee are charged.<n>They are accused of plotting to kill a former inmate who was getting out of prison.<n>An FBI informant met the men after infiltrating a branch of the KKK, WJXT reports.
The site of this week's nuclear talks is a gilded cage.<n>The Beau-Rivage Palace Hotel has hosted diplomatic events before.<n>John Kerry: "People negotiated hard"
Al-Shabaab claims responsibility for the attack.<n>Four of the dead were UNICEF workers.<n>The Somali President calls it "an attack against the future of our country"

Prince Harry visits the Australian War Memorial in Canberra.<n>He'll spend four weeks with the country's military, training in Sydney, Darwin and Perth.<n>The prince announced last month that he was leaving the British Army in June.
Australia's foreign minister says the deal is "an informal arrangement"<n>She says Iran was "very agreeable" to share intelligence.
"Work is continuing to establish the precise history of the flight," BEA says.<n>Investigators have found 470 personal effects at the crash site, prosecutor says.

Conservationists rescue crew of alleged poaching vessel.<n>Sea Shepherd had been tailing the Thunder for 110 days.<n>The Thunder is subject to an Interpol "purple notice" for suspected fraud and fisheries-related crimes.

Huntley High School in suburban Chicago is using blended learning.<n>The program combines Internet-based instruction with a more traditional classroom setting.<n>One-third of the school's 2,700 students are enrolled.

Kenya launches airstrikes against Al-Shabaab in Somalia, military source says.<n>Kenyan authorities had intelligence that a university attack was coming, source says.<n>Kenya's foreign minister denies reports that the response was insufficient.
Pope Francis asks for peace in Iraq, Syria, the Holy Land and Ukraine.<n>He also asks for peace from drug dealers, corrupt officials and arms dealers.
Duke University students and faculty members march after a noose was found hanging from a tree.<n>"This is no Duke we will accept," the school's president tells a crowd at a forum.
Muhanad Mahmoud Al Farekh, 29, was deported from Pakistan to the United States.<n>He's accused of plotting to fight against American forces abroad.

State media: Saudi border guard killed in cross-boundary fire exchange with militants in Yemen.<n>10 others suffered injuries that were not life-threatening, Saudi media outlet says.<n>Houthi rebels seize the presidential palace in the southern Yemeni port city of Aden, officials say.

CNN's Zain Verjee is the only Gulf national in the CNN team.<n>Verjee heads to Dubai to witness the ancient tradition of camel racing.<n>The camels are racing for thousands of dollars in prize money and fancy new cars for their owners.
Charlie Hill has lived in Cuba for 43 years.<n>He is wanted in the United States for the murder of a police officer.<n>Hill hijacked an airliner and took it to Havana.

This page includes the show Transcript.<n>Use the Transcript to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary.<n>At the bottom of the page, comment for a chance to be mentioned on CNN Student News. You must be a teacher or a student age 13 or older to request.<n>The Weekly Newsquiz tests students' knowledge of events in the news.
Misao Okawa was born on March 5, 1898.<n>She died Wednesday morning in Osaka, Japan.
Missouri National Guard used highly militarized words to describe Ferguson protesters.<n>Guard superiors later told troops to stop using heavily militarized language to describe protesters.

Al-Shabaab militants detonated a car bomb at education ministry entrance.<n>Five gunmen then entered the building, shooting people inside, officials say.<n>Somali special forces battled the gunmen inside, witnesses say.

Gregory Margolin, 87, was a sniper who fought in the Soviet Red Army during World War II.<n>He fled Ukraine with his family when the Nazis invaded and settled in Donetsk.<n>He survived the war but lost his daughter Ira to a missile attack in February.<n>His family fled Eastern Ukraine to Israel, where he has now lived for decades, suffering from Alzheimer's.

A year ago, more than 200 schoolgirls were kidnapped in Nigeria.<n>CNN's Zain Verjee says the world stood as one in the days after the abduction.<n>Verjee: The world must now unite in the search for the girls.
Norway is set to become the first in the world to phase out radio entirely.<n>Many Norwegians have already made the move.

A new study suggests the Brontosaurus belongs to its own genera.<n>Brontosaurus was first named in 1879, but was kicked from science books for more than a century.<n>The paleontologist who led the study says he is "expecting a debate"

Scores of dead fish have appeared in Rio de Janeiro's Rodrigo de Freitas lagoon.<n>Officials believe rains caused temperature change and excess of decaying organic matter.<n>The city will host the 2016 Olympic rowing and canoe competitions.

Anthony Ray Hinton was convicted of two murders and put on Alabama's death row.<n>He always said he was innocent.<n>The state dismissed the charges after firearms experts said a gun could not be linked to other evidence.

Opinion polls put David Cameron and Ed Miliband tied at the head of the pack in UK election debate.<n>Oakley: Cameron was wise to refuse all invitations to go head to head with Miliband alone in verbal fisticuffs.<n>Miliband is a perfectly capable debater, he could only gain from their confrontation,Oakman says.

A judge says Facebook is an acceptable way for a woman to serve divorce papers.<n>Ellanora Arthur Baidoo has been trying to divorce her husband for several years.<n>She has been able to reach him by phone, but he has refused to make himself available.

Italian physician Dr. Sergio Canavero says we are approaching HEAVEN.<n>He says he has part of the funding secured.<n>He hopes to get a buy-in this summer when he presents his plan to a major medical group.

Anthony Stokes carjacked someone, burglarized a home, shot at an elderly woman, police say.<n>He was carjacked a week after he received a heart transplant, police say.<n>Stokes lost control of the car, hit a pedestrian and then a pole, police say.

147 people are killed in the attack at Garissa University College, a disaster agency says.<n>A lecturer says terrorists shot Christians, then Muslims, before taking hostages.<n>Hundreds of students managed to escape, a CNN affiliate reports.
Funeral held for Freddie Gray, who died after being arrested.<n>Congressman Elijah Cummings: "Did anybody recognize Freddie Gray when he was alive?"
Chef Rick Moonen: "The Meatrix: Relaunched" is an important benchmark in the evolution of the sustainable food movement.

Mitchelle Angela Blair, 35, is charged with murder and torture in the deaths of her two children.<n>The bodies of Stoni Ann Blair, 13, and Stephen Gage Berry, 9, were found in a freezer last month.

Wladimir Klitschko tells CNN he is shocked by the ongoing conflict in his homeland Ukraine.<n>Klitschko is the reigning IBF, WBA, WBO and IBO heavyweight champion.<n>The Ukrainian says he does not want to see his country torn apart by war.
Michael Keaton hosted "Saturday Night Live" for the third time.<n>He paid homage to his iconic roles in "Beetlejuice" and "Batman"<n>Critics were mostly pleased with the performance.

Police say they are investigating a "slow and painstaking" forensic examination.<n>Thieves reportedly got away with hundreds of thousands of pounds worth of gems and cash.<n>Police say about 60-70 safe deposit boxes were opened during the burglary.

Iran's defiance to halt its controversial nuclear program has defined Ayatollah Ali Khamenei's era.<n>The standoff with the West has stretched longer than the war.<n>If Iran can finalize a deal by June, international investors, including Americans, would be able to invest in Iran for the first time in decades, writes Fathi.

The idea of sustainable development is that raw capitalism is far too powerful for its own good, says Andrew Hammond.<n>Hammond: Untrammeled greed also leads to massive fraud, mega-tax evasion, pervasive bribery, modern slavery, rising inequalities, and environmental destruction.
The U.S. is faced with a troubling reality -- we are far too reliant on Russian technology.<n>The Ukraine crisis should have served as a wake-up call, says Mark Hertling.
Malala Yousafzai writes an open letter to the Nigerian schoolgirls abducted a year ago.<n>"We will never forget you. We will always stand with you," she writes.

Pakistan condemns the attack, vows to catch the militants.<n>Three militants were killed by Iranian forces, state-run media reports.<n>An anti-Iranian militant group claims responsibility, Iranian state media reports.

Ferguson holds its first city election since Michael Brown's death.<n>African-Americans are running for three seats on the City Council.<n>One of the candidates is a lawyer and criminal justice professor.
Police spokesman Micky Rosenfeld: A 37-year-old Arab motorist struck two people at a bus stop.<n>One victim died at the hospital, the other is in serious condition.

Lauren Bacall's art collection sells for $3.64 million.<n>The 750-piece collection features bronze sculptures, jewelry, and decorative arts and paintings.<n>Among the artists Bacall loved were Henry Moore and Jean Schlumberger.
Oleg Kalashnikov, a former member of parliament, was shot and killed Wednesday.<n>A day later, journalist Oles Buzyna, 45, was killed by shots fired from a dark blue Ford Focus.
Chile's president signs a law allowing same-sex civil unions.<n>The law gives same-sex couples greater rights in the realms of property, health care, pensions and inheritance.
After a century of development, half the Everglades is dead and the other half is on life support.<n>Without this swamp, there can be no "good life" in Florida, says CNN's John Sutter.

ISIS militants have taken control of Yarmouk Palestinian refugee camp near Damascus, Syria.<n>An estimated 18,000 refugees are trapped inside Yarmouk, stuck between ISIS and Syrian regime forces.<n>The camp, formed in 1957 to accommodate people fleeing the Arab-Israeli conflict, has been engulfed in fighting since 2012.

Andreas Lubitz suffered from suicidal tendencies before his career, prosecutor's office says.<n>He underwent psychotherapy before getting his pilot's license, spokesman said.
Houthi leader: "Anyone who thinks we will surrender is dreaming"<n>Saudi military official says airstrikes have weakened the Houthis.

LZ: Barney Frank told audience in Chicago not to worry about California gay killing proposal.<n>LZ: "We're winning" is a phrase we've heard a lot recently as it pertains to LGBT rights.

Al-Shabaab is a Somali group that the United States designated as a foreign terrorist organization in 2008.<n>It wants to turn Somalia into a fundamentalist Islamic state.<n>The group has been blamed for attacks in Somalia that have killed international aid workers, journalists, civilian leaders and African Union peacekeepers.
Cecil Rhodes' statue was first unveiled at the University of Cape Town in 1934.<n>Students took to social media to demand his statue come down.
The death toll in Syria has doubled in a year, an opposition group says.<n>The United Nations says half of all Syrians are in dire need of survival aid.
Ailina Tsarnaeva is the sister of Dzhokhar and Tamerlan Tsarnaev.<n>She is accused of making bomb threats against a woman.
A Gaza man says he sold a door bearing a Banksy drawing for $175.<n>The iron door will remain in the possession of the Khan Younis police until a court hearing.

Scotland face Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier on September 4.<n>UEFA have opened disciplinary proceedings against the Georgian Football Federation.<n>Fans invaded the pitch twice during Georgia's 2-0 defeat by Germany.<n>Scotland currently sit third in Group D, a point behind leaders Poland.

David Moore, 25, went berserk with road rage after leaving his home.<n>He punched Rafal Cegielka, 45, who was picking up his child from school.<n>Moore then jumped out of his vehicle and punched Mr Cegielka.<n>He then ripped away a fencing panel from a nearby garden and chased him.<n>Finally he armed himself with a hockey stick and shouted: 'I'll f***ing kill him'<n>He admitted assault by beating and damaging Mr Cegielka's car.<n>He was given 16 weeks in prison, suspended for two years.

Spain lost 2-0 to Holland at the Amsterdam Arena on Tuesday.<n>It was Spain's third straight friendly defeat since last summer's World Cup.<n>Vicente del Bosque fielded a largely experimental team against Holland.<n>Spain host Slovakia in a Euro 2016 qualifier in September.

Ulrike Berger, 44, barred from leaving country with daughter Kaia, 7.<n>Pair last seen at her Brooklyn home on March 21, when Kaia's father dropped her off.<n>Believed to have boarded plane to Germany on March 22.

Blaze sparked by suspected arsonists in three locations in Dorset yesterday.<n>Flames up to 35ft high spread rapidly through the nature reserve.<n>More than 80 firefighters spent six hours tackling the blaze.<n>Fire investigators have confirmed the fire was started deliberately.<n>Two schoolboys, aged 14 and 15, have been arrested on suspicion of arson.

London Ambulance Service received 638 calls in the first hour of 2013.<n>London Police made 77 arrests and had 10 calls every minute after midnight.<n>A Territorial Army field hospital was set-up in Cambridge to deal with drunks.
Simon Mignolet was dropped by Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers.<n>The Belgian goalkeeper returned after Brad Jones was injured.<n>Mignolet has been in impressive form since his return.

Twitter user Arke USA from Bryant, Arkansas, filmed the ice balls peppering his backyard and noisily plopping into the swimming pool.<n>The National Weather Service received 170 reports of hail on Tuesday, twenty of which detailed stones at least two inches in diameter.<n>Storms will move across the Midwest on Thursday with St Louis, Louisville, Memphis, Indianapolis, Little Rock, Oklahoma City and Dallas hit hardest.

The Liana's Ransom lost power off the coast of Maine early Monday morning.<n>The Canadian charter ship was headed to St Maarten when it encountered difficulties.<n>The Coast Guard sent two lifeboats to try and tow the vessel to shore, but 10-foot swells caused a tow line to break.<n>The crew was forced to abandon ship and jump into the water.<n>One crew member was airlifted to the hospital after striking his head while jumping.

Incredible pictures have emerged of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast.<n>The images were taken in Jervis Bay, the south coast of NSW, as the neon glow illuminated one of Australia's popular beaches.<n>Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight as a 'beautiful supernatural scene' caused by millions of plankton.<n>A similar display was shown in Sydney's Manly Beach back in August 2014.

Rahul Kumar, 17, climbed into the enclosure at Kamla Nehru Zoological Park.<n>He ran towards the animals shouting 'Today I kill a lion or a lion kills me!'<n>Fortunately, he fell into a moat before being rescued by zoo security.<n>He later explained that he was drunk and thought he'd'stand a good chance'

The 12-year-old boy from Nanchang fell from the fourth floor of this building while sleepwalking, according to his father.<n>The incident happened last Saturday in Nanchang.<n>Doctors said that the boy did not have life-threatening injuries.

Red Wings forward Drew Miller was cut on his cheek and eye during Tuesday's game against the Senators.<n>He was struck by Ottawa's Mark Stone's skate while battling for the puck.<n>Miller was left with a large scar across his eye, but said his eyesight was largely unaffected.<n>He is expected to return to the ice Thursday against Boston.

Filipe Luis signed a three-year contract when he moved from Atletico Madrid.<n>Atletico hope that may give them leverage in the transfer market.<n>The defender says he wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract.

Charlie Sumner ran topless on to the pitch during Reading's game with Bradford.<n>The 20-year-old also performed a series of somersaults on the pitch.<n>Footage of the stunt went viral and Sumner was charged with a public order.<n>He said he had no regrets and that he had done it for 'laugh'

Terrifying footage shows van carrying football fans veering across road.<n>Vehicle is seen travelling at such speed it is sent flying on to its side.<n>Men on roof rack sent flying as van crashes down on to one side.<n>Incident happened near the coastal city of Salé in Morocco.
England will face Holland, Italy and Ireland in Group D.<n>The Young Lions are the defending European champions.<n>Scotland have been placed in Group C alongside Greece, Russia and France.

Elephant was relaxing in the Kruger National Park in South Africa.<n>Bull approached, much to the elephant's annoyance.<n>In a gesture captured on camera, the elephant squirts the bull with water.<n>But the animal misses its target and carries on drinking.

Michael Thorpe was convicted of illegally showing Premier League games.<n>He showed the games on Albanian channels because he could not afford Sky.<n>But he has now had his conviction overturned after eight years of legal battle.<n>Landlord says he has paid a heavy price for the lengthy legal battle.<n>He says the court action has seen him lose the Stoke Inn in Plymouth.

Windsor Park suffered overnight damage to its West Stand.<n>The Irish Football Association is awaiting a report from structural engineers.<n>The next qualifier for Michael O'Neill's side is against Romania on June 13.

Charlie Sumner, 20, staged a one-man pitch invasion at Madejski Stadium.<n>He ran topless onto the pitch and performed a series of somersaults.<n>Reading supporter was tackled by stewards during FA cup quarter final.<n>He is now facing a potential three-year ban for the stunt at his first game.<n>Today, he said he had done it for 'laugh' and that his family had'seen the funny side'

Hina Shamim was walking to library after finishing her dissertation.<n>BMW driver crashed into double decker then hit Miss Shamim.<n>Witnesses said car was travelling at around 80mph when it hit her.<n>Miss Shamim was pronounced dead at the scene in Kingston, London.<n>Friends have left tributes to the'most charming lovely girl in the world'<n>34-year-old man driver arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving.

The mother and daughter were caught on camera at Langham Creek High School, in Houston on Tuesday.<n>The mother, who has not been identified, was reportedly angry with the girl because she had allegedly been bullying her daughter.<n>The video, which was posted online, but has now been taken down.

Stoke goalkeeper Asmir Begovic has been linked with a move away.<n>Potters chief executive Tony Scholes is hopeful they can keep hold of him.<n>Jack Butland and Mark Hughes have also signed new deals with the club.

Winston Reid has been out of action since injuring his hamstring in a 1-0 defeat by Chelsea on March 4.<n>Valencia missed West Ham's last two games against Arsenal and Sunderland following a bizarre toe injury suffered at home in mid-March.<n>Big Sam feels Nigel Pearson has received unfair criticism in recent months.

Brittany Huber and John Redman were involved in a deadly car crash on their way to marry last May.<n>The bride to be was killed on impact and Redman was left clinging to life.<n>The 25-year-old survived but was told he would be confined to a wheelchair for life.<n>On March 24, Redman helped lead his team to its first-ever championship.

Lucas enjoyed a run of 16 starts in 19 matches from late November.<n>The Brazil international suffered a groin problem in February and missed 10 games.<n>Lucas played 90 minutes in Sunday's All-Star Charity game at Anfield.

Japanese photographer Yki Aoyama's latest series of images capture po-faced teenagers.<n>In each picture the daughter looks directly into the camera smiling while her father pulls a dramatic pose.<n>The 37-year-old's images are said to be part of a book which roughly translates as Daughter and Salary Man.

Police hunting man aged 50 to 60 suspected of robbing a bank in broad daylight.<n>Robbery took place at 12.30pm at a Lloyds Bank branch in Fairwater, Cardiff.<n>Detectives have issued CCTV images of the suspect, who is 5ft 9in to 6ft.<n>He was wearing black clothing and greying black hair, police said.

Morocco were banned from the next two African Cup of Nations tournaments.<n>The country pulled out as hosts due to Ebola fears.<n>The ban has now been lifted by the Court of Arbitration for Sport.<n>Morocco can now compete in the 2017 and 2019 tournaments.

Jason Denayer has impressed on loan at Celtic this season.<n>The 19-year-old recently won his first Belgium cap against Cyprus.<n>Tom Boyd believes Denayer is ready to challenge for Manchester City place.

Andros Townsend scored England's equaliser in their 1-1 friendly draw with Italy on Tuesday night.<n>The Tottenham winger said naysayers like Paul Merson provided motivation for him in Italy.<n>Roy Hodgson has kept faith with the 23-year-old despite his ups and downs this season.

Wanda Group have bought a 20 per cent stake in Atletico Madrid.<n>The Chinese property conglomerate hope to grow Atletico's brand in Asia.<n>Diego Simeone's side have won the La Liga title on four occasions.

Ian Murray believes Hibs have the easier run-in.<n>Rangers have two games in hand but Murray believes they will struggle.<n>Murray believes Rangers will need to beat Queen of the South and Raith Rovers to maintain their pace.

Simon Mignolet has returned to England after international duty with Belgium.<n>The Liverpool goalkeeper posed for pictures with pilots in an aeroplane cockpit as he returned home.<n>Mignolet was included in the Belgium match-day squad for their Euro 2016 qualifying games against Cyprus and Israel.<n>Chelsea stopper Thibaut Courtois was preferred to Mignolet in either game.<n>Mignolet has kept six consecutive clean sheets away from home in the Premier League.

Chyknell Hall Estate is set in 200 acres of land near Bridgnorth, Shropshire, and boasts a Grade II-listed manor house.<n>Property also boasts a swimming pool, tennis court, stables - and even its own cricket green.<n> Regency home could attract A-list buyers as secluded grounds offer residents complete privacy.

The incident occurred at El Centro College and was captured on cell phone by student Charles Adams.<n>The officers approached the high school students while they were waiting for a bus outside the downtown Dallas campus.<n>The footage shows the young men being ordered to face a brick wall, while one of the two campus cops searched, questioned, and even hit one of the teens.<n>The school reportedly won't say why the teens were stopped and frisked, but Adams said he believes the officers totally overreacted.
Gary Locke has been given the job on a permanent basis.<n>The 39-year-old has signed a three-year deal at Rugby Park.<n>Locke has lost just once in seven games since taking over.

Borussia Dortmund and Bayern Munich have shared the last five Bundesliga titles between them and Bayern are set to continue their domestic domination this term.<n>The two giant antagonists of the German game meet with 31 points and nine positions separating them in the standings.<n>Victory would nevertheless be important for Dortmund if they are to close the gap on the top six and qualify for Europe next season.

Deva Joseph, 14, was left in tears at London Stansted airport.<n>She was told she would not be allowed to take her flight home to Spain.<n>The teenager offered to pay for the second item to be put in the hold.<n>But she was told only credit cards would be accepted.

Gordon Robson, 26, was drunk after his grandfather's funeral.<n>He got into an argument with John Potts outside a sports bar.<n>Mr Potts stepped in to stop the fighting and Robson hit him in the head.<n>Robson was jailed for just three and a half years for the attack.
Ellen White scored against her former club in the Women's Super League.<n>The Notts County star also missed a penalty in the 1-1 draw.<n>White spent three seasons at Arsenal before joining County.

The girls aged between 16 and 18 are undergoing five-day training.<n>They are being taught by a former special forces solider called Inspector Tan.<n>The knives are not real but school officials say they pose no danger.<n>Once trained the girls will be able to use any sharp implement to defend themselves.

A study has revealed that 30 percent of Australians complain about their lack of sleep on a daily basis.<n>The average adult needs around eight hours of sleep per night.<n>Pushing sleep-debt boundaries can lead to micro sleeps in certain people.<n>20 minute power naps are advised to avoid falling into deep sleep.

The clip was uploaded to Facebook today.<n>It shows a woman unleashing a racist tirade over her fence.<n>The woman then appears in her neighbour's front yard brandishing a metal crowbar, verbally abusing the men and swinging the weapon at them.<n>The men then pick up their own weapons and a scuffle breaks out.<n>After a second tussle, the woman appears to be struck in the face.

Jose Luis Gaya is a left-back who likes to get forward at every opportunity.<n>The 19-year-old has a £13.5m buy-out clause at Valencia.<n>Manchester City, Arsenal and Chelsea are all interested in signing him.

Police in Oregon are enlisting the help of the public to identify a mystery motorcyclist who saved the day after Edward West, 59, allegedly threatened two teens with a handgun.<n>The boys say they didn't get a good look at the rider, but the Marion County Sheriff's office is asking the public to help identify the friendly neighborhood motorcyclist.

Ron Vlaar returns to Aston Villa squad for trip to Old Trafford on Saturday.<n>Tim Sherwood urges captain to prove his worth to the club.<n>Dutch defender starred in Holland's run to the World Cup semi-finals.

Aston Villa are in talks with a prospective buyer, it is understood.<n>But manager Tim Sherwood insists he is not concerned by the situation.<n>Villa are currently three points above the relegation zone in 16th.<n>They face Manchester United at Old Trafford on Saturday.

Jason Denayer has impressed on loan at Celtic this season.<n>But Manchester City are keen to invest in their Academy.<n>The likes of Denayer may return from loan deals to fill the gap.<n>Premier League clubs must carry eight homegrown players next season.

Fraser Forster suffered a serious knee injury against Burnley.<n>The England goalkeeper has undergone surgery but will be out for months.<n>Ronald Koeman would not be drawn on whether Southampton will sign a new keeper in the summer.<n>Southampton travel to Everton in the Premier League on Saturday.

Birmingham City defeated Rotherham United 2-1 in the Championship.<n>Robert Tesche and Clayton Donaldson scored for the hosts.<n>Matt Derbyshire pulled one back for the Millers.<n>But referee Dean Whitestone denied Rotherham a penalty.

Virgil van Dijk has never been capped by Holland.<n>The Celtic defender was called up to the Dutch squad last year.<n>But Guus Hiddink has never been impressed with the defender.<n>Van Dijk says he was happy for team-mate Jason Denayer to make his debut for Belgium against Israel.

Celtic face Inverness in the Scottish Cup semi-final at Hampden later this month.<n>The North and South stands will cost £23 for adults and £5 for concessions.<n>The East Stand will cost £15 for adults and £5 for concessions.<n>The SFA have responded by saying the prices have not changed in four years.

Rangers will be forced to delist from the Alternative Investment Market.<n>The Ibrox outfit will be unable to secure a new nominated advisor.<n>Interim chairman Paul Murray insists the new board’s plans for the future will be unaffected.

England drew 1-1 with Italy in Turin on Tuesday night.<n>Graziano Pelle opened the scoring for the hosts in the first half.<n>Andros Townsend equalised for Roy Hodgson's side.<n>Wayne Rooney said England were upset by their first half performance.<n>He said they knew they were better than that and were disappointed.

Dundee United have hit back at criticism from two leading supporters' groups.<n>Arabtrust and the Federation of Dundee United Supporters Clubs say they are'shocked' that 25 per cent of £6.3million worth of transfer fees were paid in commission to unnamed parties.<n>The supporters groups also disputed chairman Stephen Thompson's alleged level of investment in the club.
Gary Locke has been in temporary charge of Kilmarnock since February.<n>The 39-year-old will be confirmed as the club's new manager on Friday.<n>Locke has been given a three-year deal at Rugby Park.
Mai Zizhuo has been shooting hoops since he was two and a half years old.<n>His incredible skills have won him legions of fans across basketball-mad China.

David Alaba has been ruled out for around seven weeks with a torn knee ligament.<n>The Bayern Munich left-back was injured playing for Austria on Tuesday.<n>Alaba had been in superb form since his return from injury.<n>The 22-year-old will start rehabilitation work in about a month.

Dane Tilse has signed a two-and-a-half-year deal with Hull KR.<n>The 6ft 7in forward will link up with his old Canberra team-mate Terry Campese.<n>The Raiders have agreed to release the forward.<n>Hull KR have been short on front row props after the retirements of Michael Weyman and Ryan Bailey.

Darren Cole's cousin Shaun was found dead in a Miami street last weekend.<n>Cole was granted time off by Livingston as they prepare for the final.<n>But the midfielder returned to training on Wednesday and could play.

Alan Smith suffered a broken leg and dislocated ankle during the 2006 FA Cup fifth round exit to Liverpool.<n>The former Manchester United midfielder was travelling to hospital when he was attacked by Liverpool fans.<n>But Smith has denied that the ambulance he was travelling to hospital in was attacked by Liverpool fans.<n>CLICK HERE for all the latest Manchester United news.

Celtic are considering a £400,000 bid for Hearts captain Danny Wilson.<n>The defender is out of contract at the end of the season.<n>But Hearts are in no rush to sell and Wilson could stay at the club.<n>Virgil van Dijk and Jason Denayer are both attracting interest.

Celtic lost 4-1 to Legia Warsaw in Champions League qualifying.<n>Ronny Deila says the club will not embark on another gruelling pre-season.<n>The Bhoys have played games in the United States, Austria, Germany and Australia in the past.

Kevin de Bruyne has been linked with a move to Bayern Munich.<n>The Wolfsburg playmaker has been in impressive form this season.<n>But Franck Ribery says he is the wrong type of player for the club.<n>The Frenchman says De Bruyne's counter-attacking skills don't mesh with the style of Pep Guardiola.<n>Click here for more Bayern Munich club news.

Davon Durant, a promising linebacker at Arizona State University, was arrested on domestic violence charges March 7.<n>His girlfriend of 18 months, Kelsi Langley, claimed that he hit her in the face and grabbed her neck during an argument in his car.<n>The 19-year-old held a press conference on campus Tuesday declaring that she lied about the assault because she was jealous.

Detroit Tigers pitcher Justin Verlander snapped a selfie in front a little boy wearing a dark blue shirt with Verlander's name and jersey number, 35, on the back.<n>The pitcher uploaded the selfie to his more than 150,000 Instagram followers writing: 'Love having my fans support!! This little guy was pretty surprised when he turned around'

Eden Hazard was substituted with 28 minutes to go in Belgium's 1-0 win over Israel on Tuesday night.<n>The Chelsea playmaker has played all but five of his side's games this season.<n>Hazard questioned manager Marc Wilmots after the game about whether he was tired.<n>Wilmots said he felt Hazard was tired, something the playmaker questioned.<n>Hazard has played 48 games for club and country this season.

Police discovered 20 grams of marijuana hidden within a leg of lamb.<n>The stash would have been worth $2000 if it had been sold.<n>It is believed the lamb had been shipped to a company at Darwin Airport.<n>The sender would be 'feeling a little sheepish' after their attempt was sniffed out.
